GWAScopeR 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Plot Cumulative Variance Explained by Principal Components

    plot_cumulative_variance.Rd

    This function performs Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on a genotype matrix and generates a plot showing the cumulative variance explained by the principal components. The plot includes a dashed line representing the given variance threshold, and the number of principal components (PCs) required to exceed this threshold is annotated.

    plot_cumulative_variance(X, variance_threshold = 0.80, remove_NAs = FALSE)

    Arguments

    X

    A matrix or data frame containing genotype data, where rows represent samples and columns represent SNPs. The first column is assumed to be an ID column (if non-numeric, it will be removed), and all SNP columns should contain numeric values 0, 1, or 2, with optional NA values.

    variance_threshold

    A numeric value between 0 and 1 specifying the cumulative variance threshold for determining the number of PCs to retain. Default is 0.80.

    remove_NAs

    A logical value indicating whether to remove rows with missing values (NA). If `TRUE`, rows with missing values will be removed. Default is `FALSE`.

    Details

    This function performs PCA on the input genotype matrix and calculates the cumulative variance explained by the principal components. A plot is generated with the cumulative variance on the y-axis and the number of principal components on the x-axis. A dashed line is drawn at the specified variance threshold, and the number of principal components required to reach the threshold is highlighted.

    Value

    A numeric value indicating the number of principal components needed to explain at least the specified variance threshold.

    References

    Author

    Michelle Marcano-Delgado

    Note

    If there are missing values in the genotype matrix and `remove_NAs` is set to `FALSE`, the function will stop with an error.

    See also

    prcomp, complete.cases, ggplot2

    Examples

      # Example 1: Plot cumulative variance with a variance threshold of 80%
  plot_cumulative_variance(X, variance_threshold = 0.80)
#> Error in plot_cumulative_variance(X, variance_threshold = 0.8): object 'X' not found

  # Example 2: Remove rows with NA values and use a 90% variance threshold
  plot_cumulative_variance(X, variance_threshold = 0.90, remove_NAs = TRUE)
#> Error in plot_cumulative_variance(X, variance_threshold = 0.9, remove_NAs = TRUE): object 'X' not found
